data.title: Every UK #1 Single of the 1960's Discussion Thread
data.meta_description:
Tell Laura I love her
A pretty good teen death ballad. Jeff Barry sure had a lot more to give yet. I prefer Ray Peterson's voice to Valance's.
data.text:
I just discovered by looking at the Amazon 'look inside' feature that the 'records by artist' books in this new series, each titled as "Hits Book", are combining all records together, chronologically. Singles, EPs, and albums for each artist are all mixed together by chart entry date. I've never seen this before, I sure don't like it. When Guinness published their combined singles and albums books, they kept them in separate blocks.

Another feature, each "Hits Book" lists all the album tracks under each album. While this may be a good thing, it takes up a huge amount of space/pages, around 40% more. Which the author then reduces by printing everything in small print, which drives me batty as I then have to pull out a magnifying glass to read everything. It would be better to put album tracks in separate books, thus allowing all chart performance info to be in a larger 'normal' print size. When I need to know an album track listing, I always go to the internet, Discogs, AllMusic, etc. I buy chart books for chart performance information, not for album track listings.

And while the author includes a lot of UK chart history in the introductions of these books, he (1) selectively includes some historical information to justify the 'official' charts decision in choosing Record Retailer to represent the 60s, (2) ignores other historical information that totally shoots it down, and (3) includes statements that are totally false. Revised history by selection, totally dishonest, and not the way it was.

If you buy a chart book to get an approximate view of chart history, then these new books for the UK 60s will be good enough for you. The big hits are the same big hits across all the charts, peak chart positions are relatively close. But if you are concerned about accuracy as well, then you should seek out the Melody Maker charts (the best, in internet land), or NME (the next best, in internet land, and in the NME 1990s out of print chart books), or even the BBC average charts (in internet land). Record Retailer is the least representative/least accurate chart of the 60s, fact. They only represented around 13% of the sampled record shops in the UK over the decade, while Melody Maker represented over 40%. But you won't hear this info from the Official Charts Co.

Even with their faults, these 60s books are still a good thing, so buy buy buy. But just realize what you are getting...
